whys.question: Why did the two aircraft collide on the runway?

options.text: One aircraft began its take-off run without proper clearance.
options.feedback: Correct – this was the immediate cause.

options.text: It was a night-time operation with poor lighting.
options.feedback: Partially true – lighting wasn’t the primary factor here.

options.text: Both aircraft were trying to land on the same runway.
options.feedback: Incorrect – one was taxiing for take-off, the other was stationary.

options.text: Dense fog reduced visibility to near zero.
options.feedback: Yes, but this was a contributing factor rather than the initiating cause.

options.text: Ground radar failed completely.
options.feedback: Not applicable – the airport had no ground radar at the time.

whys.question: Why did the aircraft begin its take-off without clearance?

options.text: Miscommunication between the flight crew and ATC.
options.feedback: Correct – clearance was misunderstood.

options.text: The tower instructed both aircraft to line up and wait.
options.feedback: True, but this alone didn’t trigger the roll.

options.text: The pilot was under time pressure due to duty limits.
options.feedback: Yes, this added stress but wasn't the sole cause.

options.text: ATC cleared the take-off immediately.
options.feedback: No – the clearance was never given explicitly.

options.text: Crew thought they heard a clearance during a blocked transmission.
options.feedback: Yes – radio overlap caused critical words to be missed.

options.text: Simultaneous transmissions caused key phrases to be blocked.
options.feedback: Exactly – partial messages led to assumptions.

options.text: The ATC frequency had excessive background noise.
options.feedback: Possible distraction, but not the root issue.

options.text: One crew member mistranslated ATC English.
options.feedback: No – both crews and ATC used standard ICAO English.

options.text: Non-standard phraseology added ambiguity.
options.feedback: Yes – deviations from ICAO phraseology increased risk.

options.text: ATC didn’t use read-back confirmation for clearances.
options.feedback: Correct – poor confirmation discipline worsened confusion.

options.text: The VHF radio system allowed transmissions to overlap without warning.
options.feedback: Correct – no anti-blocking mechanism existed.

options.text: A secondary backup frequency was in use.
options.feedback: No – all aircraft were on the same primary frequency.

options.text: Cockpit crew failed to monitor all transmissions.
options.feedback: True – but this was partly due to fog and workload.

options.text: Poor discipline in radio use from multiple parties.
options.feedback: Yes – congestion increased the chance of overlaps.

options.text: The radios were set to half-duplex mode.
options.feedback: Incorrect – VHF is always half-duplex by design.

whys.question: Why was there poor situational awareness?

options.text: Thick fog prevented visual confirmation of runway status.
options.feedback: Exactly – visual cues were lost.

options.text: The airport layout required complex taxiing.
options.feedback: Yes – the unfamiliar layout increased complexity.

options.text: Runway lighting was switched off accidentally.
options.feedback: No – lighting was on, but ineffective in fog.

options.text: Limited visibility combined with high cockpit workload.
options.feedback: Correct – workload degraded scanning and monitoring.

options.text: ATC had full radar visibility but failed to act.
options.feedback: Incorrect – ATC had no ground radar.

whys.question: Why did the aircraft ditch in the Hudson River?

options.text: Both engines lost thrust after bird strikes.
options.feedback: Correct – this was the initiating event.

options.text: The pilots decided not to attempt a runway return.
options.feedback: Yes – but this was a decision after the loss of thrust.

options.text: Fuel contamination caused flameout.
options.feedback: Incorrect – no contamination was found.

options.text: Bird strikes occurred shortly after take-off.
options.feedback: Yes – but it’s part of the same initiating event.

options.text: The weather was stormy with lightning strikes.
options.feedback: No – conditions were clear.

whys.question: Why did both engines fail after bird strikes?

options.text: Bird ingestion damaged fan blades and compressors.
options.feedback: Correct – damage was beyond recovery.

options.text: One engine ingested multiple large birds; the other ingested at least one.
options.feedback: Yes – but the root is in engine vulnerability.

options.text: The engines were overdue for maintenance.
options.feedback: No – maintenance was up-to-date.

options.text: The birds were Canada geese, large and numerous.
options.feedback: Yes – species size increased the damage severity.

options.text: The aircraft was flying through a migratory corridor without mitigation measures.
options.feedback: Yes – no dispersal was in effect.

whys.question: Why was there no opportunity to avoid the birds?

options.text: The birds were encountered unexpectedly at 2,800 feet.
options.feedback: Exactly – little time to react.

options.text: The flight crew failed to scan for birds visually.
options.feedback: No – birds were not visible in time.

options.text: Bird radars weren’t in use at the airport.
options.feedback: Yes – such systems existed but weren’t deployed here.

options.text: The airspace was uncontrolled and unsupervised.
options.feedback: Incorrect – it was controlled airspace.

options.text: No wildlife management measures were active that morning.
options.feedback: Yes – this is a procedural gap.

whys.question: Why was ditching chosen over returning to an airport?

options.text: Insufficient altitude and speed to reach a runway.
options.feedback: Correct – performance calculations confirmed it.

options.text: The captain had prior ditching experience.
options.feedback: No – this was his first actual ditching.

options.text: Returning risked endangering more lives over populated areas.
options.feedback: Yes – but the primary driver was physics.

options.text: The first officer recommended ditching immediately.
options.feedback: CRM supported the decision, but wasn’t sole reason.

options.text: ATC advised against any runway attempt.
options.feedback: Incorrect – ATC offered runways, but the crew declined.

whys.question: Why was the ditching successful with no fatalities?

options.text: Exceptional crew decision-making, CRM, and skill.
options.feedback: Exactly – textbook example of teamwork.

options.text: Calm water and good visibility aided the ditching.
options.feedback: True – conditions helped but weren’t the main factor.

options.text: Cabin crew executed rapid and effective evacuation.
options.feedback: Yes – but this followed the safe landing.

options.text: The aircraft type was designed for water landings.
options.feedback: No – the A320 is not amphibious.

options.text: The fuselage remained intact, limiting water ingress.
options.feedback: Yes – structural integrity played a role.
